recommendations.title: What Surprised Me the Most About Being a Jeopardy! Champ

recommendations.title: Here’s What “Millennial Burnout” Is Like For 16 Different People
recommendations.excerpt: I grew up in a conservative religious home in rural Pennsylvania, part of a radically right-wing splinter group. I tell people I was home-schooled. Really, I wasn’t schooled at all — I taught myself and my little brothers out of books from the library.

recommendations.title: The End of iTunes
recommendations.excerpt: Another year, another CES. Which I didn’t go to — I’ve still amazingly never been, and I could not be less sad about that.¹ Anyway, it’s beyond old hat to rag on CES these days. And there was news out of the event that I found interesting this year — and yes, it involved Apple.

recommendations.title: How To Beat Procrastination (Backed by Science)
recommendations.excerpt: Procrastination has been around since the start of modern civilization. Historical figures like Herodotus, Leonardo Da Vinci, Pablo Picasso, Benjamin Franklin, Eleanor Roosevelt, and hundreds of others have talked about how procrastination is the enemy of results.

recommendations.title: 50 Ways To Live On Your Own Terms
recommendations.excerpt: Although people think they perform better on caffeine, the truth is, they really don’t. Actually, we’ve become so dependent on caffeine that we use it to simply get back to our status-quo. When we’re off it, we under perform and become incapable. Isn’t this absurd?

recommendations.title: 120 Movies, $13 Billion in Box Office: How Samuel L. Jackson Became Hollywood's Most Bankable Star
recommendations.excerpt: The box office king and Trump golf antagonist beat a crack addiction to build a film career unrivaled in modern stardom, and the 70-year-old 'Glass' actor aims to work well into his 80s — if Marvel and the rest of Hollywood can afford him: "I'm a gunslinger now.

recommendations.title: What the Best Mentors Do
recommendations.excerpt: Mentorship comes in many flavors. It doesn’t always work unless leaders bear in mind a few common principles.

recommendations.title: Can't Afford an MBA? Read These 6 Books to Educate Yourself Instead
recommendations.excerpt: Many entrepreneurs find themselves, at one time or another, wondering if they should go back to school to earn an MBA degree. It’s an understandable concern.

recommendations.title: How an emerging African megacity cut commutes by two hours a day
recommendations.excerpt: Dusk falls in Dar es Salaam, and for hundreds of thousands of people in this African megacity-to-be the daily chaos and frustration of the journey home begins. People cram themselves into dalla dalla minibuses, some even climbing through the windows once the entrance is blocked.

recommendations.title: The Ministry of Mr. Rogers
recommendations.excerpt: In his own remembrances, Fred Rogers’s childhood was a little sad, with a loving but overprotective mother and a father whose life was devoted to the manufacturing business he hoped his son would take over.

recommendations.title: Who Is MacKenzie Bezos?

recommendations.title: Repeated radio signals are coming from a galaxy 1.5 billion light years away
recommendations.excerpt: Scientists have spotted repeated blasts of radio signals coming from deep in space. The breakthrough is only the second time scientists have seen such a repeating radio burst.

recommendations.title: Inside the Rise of Keto: How an Extreme Diet Went Mainstream
recommendations.excerpt: Greyson Lopez’s friend was about to be kicked out of the military for being too chubby. It was late 2017, and Lopez noticed his friend started losing weight—fast. “He’d lost 20 pounds in 20 days,” says Lopez, 23, who works in IT for the Navy.

recommendations.title: Train Your Brain Like a Memory Champion
recommendations.excerpt: If you have trouble remembering names, faces or phone numbers, these tips from memory champions and neuroscientists can help. You slide the key into the door and hear a clunk as the tumblers engage. You rotate the key, twist the doorknob and walk inside.

recommendations.title: The Art of Decision-Making
recommendations.excerpt: In July of 1838, Charles Darwin was twenty-nine years old and single. Two years earlier, he had returned from his voyage aboard H.M.S. Beagle with the observations that would eventually form the basis of “On the Origin of Species.” In the meantime, he faced a more pressing analytical problem.

recommendations.title: These 6 Types of Music Are Known to Dramatically Improve Productivity
recommendations.excerpt: Music isn’t just a means of entertaining ourselves: it can also encourage creativity and help us become more productive. Listening to music can also be therapeutic, relieving feelings of stress so you can concentrate better.

recommendations.title: The Exaggerated Promise of So-Called Unbiased Data Mining
recommendations.excerpt: Nobel laureate Richard Feynman once asked his Caltech students to calculate the probability that, if he walked outside the classroom, the first car in the parking lot would have a specific license plate, say 6ZNA74.

recommendations.title: What the chauffeur saw: what is it really like driving the rich and famous?
recommendations.excerpt: In the early hours of one morning, nearly a decade ago, chauffeur Jayne Amelia Larson found herself trying to extricate the son of one of the wealthiest men in Los Angeles from the back of her car.
